body.p:
Weakly County Tennesse
May 28th 1861
To Hon John A Gardner
Sir I refer you to a letter of introduction which you will please find herewith

I called on Govr Harris at Nashville Tennessee on Saturday last 25 Inst and had a conference with him and on the subject of Various public reports, to the effect that troops were being concentrated on the border of Kentucky awaiting the action of the Convention Called to meet at Mayfield Graves County Ky on Thursday the 30th of May Inst to take steps preparatory to Seceding from Kentucky, and annexing the several Counties West of the Tennesse river to the state of Tennessee

Altho this report is simply absurd, yet under the circumstances it is Calculated to exert a Mischievous influence upon our political affairs in Kentucky and May precipitate upon us and you, troubles which it is to the interest of both to avoid

His Excellency referd me to you as his confidential agent in this part of the state of Tennessee, and urged me to Visit you, and make known more fully his wishes togather with those of the Government and people of Ky
as shown by my letter of instructions from Governor Magoffin, (a copy of which is herewith endorsed) And from other sources within your reach

I have in conclusion to say that whilst the people of Kentucky intend to make the destiny of the Confederate States their destiny, still we must avoid precipitation of any sort and leave that question to the logic of events --

I appeal to your admitted judgement and prudence therefore, and must be permitted earnestly to hope, that no moove towards Ky, or vow her said will be made without the Consent or at the request of the legally Constituted authorities: It being the policy of Kentucky to Maintain a strict armed Neutrality as Set fourth in the proclamation of his Excellency the Governor of Kentucky bearing date the 20th May 1861, to which I beg leave to refer
Hoping to hear from you at Paducah Ky at your earliest Convenience -- I have the honor to be your obt Servt

Hon John A. Gardner
at Home
